entry.title: Re: How to enable Incoterm Location 2 field in Sales Order
entry.content:
Hello Ferdita,

Please check whether the configuration for "Map Incoterms to Versions" is maintained correctly.

SPRO Path:
Sales and Distribution â†’ Master Data â†’ Business Partners â†’ Customers â†’ Billing Document â†’ Map Incoterms to Versions

In this customizing step, each Incoterms version is assigned to the relevant Incoterms. You can also define, for each Incoterm, whether Location 1 and Location 2 are required, optional, or disabled.

Note:
Even if you enable Incoterms Location 2 in the customizing, the field will remain greyed out in the sales order if the Incoterms Version is not maintained in the Customer Master (Billing tab) or directly in the sales document.

For more information, you can refer to the documentation in the SPRO path mentioned above or open a sales order, select the Incoterms Location 2 field, and press F1 (Help) to view SAPâ€™s explanation.

Reward points if found helpful.

entry.title: Re: Integration Center fields not pulling all data
entry.content:
Hi DeAnnaW,

I had a similar issue for other fields. I would suggest checking your other field associations and calculated fields.

These can play a part in impacting what gets displayed in the data preview. 

What fixed it for me was that I had a Value Lookup Table on a field that wasn't capturing all the values in the system. Hence, for those people that had those missing values on their employee profile, it was affecting the name fields in my integration.

entry.title: Enhanced Mapping of Advanced VariantConfiguration Characteristic Values to ProductionOrder Operation
entry.content:
Introduction

With the SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 release, a valuable new feature has been introduced, 'Enhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Orders'. This enhancement allows you to map variant configuration characteristic values directly to custom fields within production routing operations. These custom fields can then be used as parameters in Work Centre formulas to dynamically calculate activities such as machine processing time, labour, and setup costs.

In this blog post, we'll explore how this feature can be applied in a real-world scenario to improve cost accuracy and operational efficiency in a manufacturing process.

Business Scenario

Imagine an automobile manufacturing company where the sit fitment time and cost vary depending on the number of seats to be installed in a custom-built caravan. In the custom-built caravan production process, the sit fitment time is calculated based on the number of seats selected by the customer during order configuration. In this case, the sit fitment time is expressed as machine time, calculated using a custom formula in the Work Centre.

Letâ€™s say the time factor is 1 for assembling 5 seats, which serves as the base configuration. We then maintain time factors of 3 for 6 seats and 5 for 7 seats to represent the proportionally higher effort and machine time required as the seat count increases, due to added installation work, alignment, and quality checks.

The table below illustrates this:

Seat Count (Z_SEAT_COUNT)

Time Factor (Z_SAFT)

Explanation

5

1

Base time unit

6

3

3Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

7

5

5Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

Consider the characteristic Z_SEAT_COUNT captures the number of seats selected. The system uses a dependency procedure (e.g., SEAT_ASSEMBLY) to calculate the machine time factor (Z_SAFT), which is then used to determine the overall operation time in routing.

This feature is especially valuable for industries that manufacture products with dynamic or customizable designsâ€”such as automotive, furniture, modular kitchens, pool tile manufacturing, or industrial machineryâ€”where production time and cost vary significantly based on configuration-specific attributes.

In the following section, weâ€™ll walk through how this use case can be implemented using the new feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud.

Prerequisites

Before implementing this feature, ensure the following prerequisites are met:

  1. Activate the Feature
    Enable the feature "Map Object Dependency Value to Operation" (FTGL_PPH_MD_MAPOBJDPNVALS_2) via the Activate Features configuration activity in your system.

  1. Create a Custom Field
    Define a custom field under the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field will be used in the Work Centre formula to calculate activities like machine, setup or labour time and cost.
    For detailed steps on how to create a custom field and incorporate it into a Work Centre formula, refer to the link below:
    ðŸ‘‰https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/step-by-step-guide-to-setting-up-custom-fields-in-work-center-formula/ba-p/14123514
  2. Create a Super Routing with Object Dependency
    Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material and assign an Object Dependency of type 'Procedure' to the relevant operation.
    For guidance on how to create a routing for configurable materials, refer to the documentation below:
    ðŸ‘‰https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f369b2eff700401494ba6e7c9a573288/d5ed07180f7a40189b043c8156157919.html?version=2502.500

Step-by-Step Execution:

1) Create and Verify Custom Field
Ensure that a custom field is created in the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field should be visible at the operation level in the routing.
In this example, weâ€™ve created a custom field called Seat Assembly Time Factor (YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO) to represent the offset value used for time and cost calculation.

2) Define Work Centre Formula
Create a Work Centre formula (e.g., Z_TIME) that uses a parameter (e.g., Z_SATF) linked to the custom field created above. This formula will be used to dynamically calculate activity times based on the selected configuration

3) Assign Formula to Work Centre Activities
Assign the custom formula (Z_TIME) to the relevant activity types (e.g., Setup, Machine, or Labour) in the Work Centre (SEATASMB) responsible for the seat assembly operation.    

4) Create Characteristic and Map to Custom Field
Define a variant configuration characteristic (e.g., Z_SATF) and map it to the custom field YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO. This enables the system to pass characteristic values to the routing operation dynamically.

5) Create Super Routing and Assign Procedure
Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material (e.g., a car model), and assign an Object Dependency of type â€˜Procedureâ€™ to the relevant operation (e.g., Seat Assembly).
In this example, the Seat Assembly Time Factor (Z_SATF) is determined based on the selected number of seats. The procedure is defined as below,

WorkCentre SEATASMB assigned to the operation 0025 â€“ Assemble Seat Units

Object dependency of type Procedure

Dependency Editor

6) Create Sales Order and Test Configuration
Once all the above steps are complete, create a Sales Order for the configurable material. On the Variant Configuration screen, select the desired number of seats.
Then, review the machine cost and overall calculated activity costs â€” they should adjust dynamically based on the selected characteristic value (i.e., the number of seats).

a) Select number of seats as â€˜5â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

b) Select number of seats as â€˜6â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 6-seater.

c) Select number of seats as â€˜7â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

Conclusion

The â€œEnhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Ordersâ€ feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 offers greater flexibility and accuracy in manufacturing configurable materials. By mapping configuration characteristics to custom fields in production operations and using them in Work Centre formulas, manufacturers can calculate activity times and costs dynamically based on real-time inputs. In the seat assembly example, processing time and cost adjust based on the number of seats selected, improving cost transparency and operational efficiency. This is especially valuable in make-to-order and engineer-to-order scenarios, where production effort varies with each configuration.

By leveraging it, businesses can better align operational planning with customer-specific configurationsâ€”driving both efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Happy Learning!!

entry.title: Improving SLA Compliance with SAP Service Cloud
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community, 

When customers reach out for support, they expect quick answers and consistent service. To meet those expectations, service teams need clear processes, defined timelines, and the right insights at every stage. This is where strong Service Level Agreement (SLA) management makes a difference.

Watch the short video introduction to see how SAP Service Cloud helps you strengthen SLA management and deliver consistent service excellence.

The new Value Package for Improving SLA Compliance with SAP Service Cloud helps you design, monitor, and continuously improve how your organization meets and exceeds service commitments.

 

Turning SLAs into Business Confidence

SLAs define the standard of service your business promises to deliver. Yet, many teams struggle to translate those standards into daily operations. The Value Package guides to:

  • Define service levels and milestones aligned with your business priorities

  • Automate SLA assignment and escalation using dynamic determination rules

  • Monitor progress in real time through dashboards and analytics

  • Empower agents with AI and machine learning insights to prevent breaches

  • Integrate SLA data across systems for full visibility and accountability

With SAP Service Cloud, you can bring consistency to customer service while reducing manual tracking and uncertainty.

 

What Youâ€™ll Find Inside the Value Package

The e-learning provides a clear journey through SLA management in SAP Service Cloud, including both Version 1 and Version 2 environments. You will explore how to configure, monitor, and optimize SLAs through guided lessons, scenarios, and practical examples.

Key learning areas include:

  • Understanding SLA concepts and milestones

  • Configuring operating hours, pause rules, and escalation logic

  • Using analytics to identify improvement opportunities

  • Connecting SLA insights to broader service performance goals

Whether you are a consultant, administrator, or business user, this Value Package will help you strengthen service operations and customer satisfaction.

 

Get Started Today

Access the complete Value Package by logging in to SAP Learning Hub, enterprise support edition, with your S-user ID or Universal ID, and then visiting the Value Package â€“ Improving SLA Compliance with SAP Service Cloud

If you would like to explore more curated learning paths, connect with SAP experts and peers, and stay current with best practices, events, and new enablement resources, join the SAP Customer Experience Value Map group in SAP Community.

Start today and improve your SLA compliance with SAP Service Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Generate PDF form on S/4HANA Cloud, public edition fr...
entry.content:
Hello @daa 
The Output Control is generic tool for all the application and therefore could be reused with the same approach in every application. But that definitely requires some technical knowledge that could be missing because Output Control is currently not officially released.

In advance I could say that for your use case the 2nd option will be the correct one, but let me comment all of your points:
1) 
     a. From SAP solution we reuse functionality of LiveCycle Designer so I would suggest to investigate further why Master Form Template could not be configured. Standard-wise there are some rules for determination of Master form template, so it is not straightforward solution like implementing it inside of the same Form.
     b.  Form Data Providers are not supposed to be released, therefore could not be accessed externally. But there is a little trick that is also described in the documentation for Billing document. Please see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/6782a95953c144f5abcde1d72f7dcb29.html
Part 1, timing 2:36. Where in Print queue name you could provide #&&DOWNLOAD_FORM_DATA_XML&&# and then during rendering you will se the data from Form Data Provider assigned to that form. 

Note: The standard application must be used with the Form and FDP that you are interested in.

2) Technically yes, the API for Output Control is not officially released yet, but in the already mentioned application 'Manage Billing Document' there is a button 'Preview' that just redirects to the CA_OC_OUTPUT_REQUEST_SRV where certain Output Request Item is previewed. For example: 
/sap/opu/odata/SAP/CA_OC_OUTPUT_REQUEST_SRV/Roots(ApplObjectType='BILLING_DOCUMENT',ApplObjectId='0090062623')/Preview/$value/
That endpoint could be accessed with GET request and same role as in main application (e.g. Manage Delivery) could be used to Print out the document. 

Note: As it is not officially released that would be on your end to understand how to use API, meaning,  you must be sure what you are doing.

3) The 'Maintain form Template' application just creates same Form Template that will behave absolutely in the same way as the standard pre-delivered one. So creating of your own Form Template is not enough. That will still not solve your issue, because you still need to access the Output outside of the ABAP system.
Well it is a combination of two first points, firstly you would need to have your own API and secondly access somehow Output Control. That solution is tricky and most probably you will end up in a limited functionality from some application area. I would not do that.

Lets  stick to the 2nd option, and in your case it will be most probably something like:
GET /sap/opu/odata/SAP/CA_OC_OUTPUT_REQUEST_SRV/Roots(ApplObjectType='OUTBOUND_DELIVERY',ApplObjectId='0080041991')/Preview/$value/

Note: I would still think about official requirement to the Output Control to have the API officially released, that will prevent any potential functionality misusage from your side.

Best Regards,
Slava Aliakseyevets

entry.title: When lowercase letters are entered as input in CONVERSION_EXIT_CUNIT_INPUT, no results appear.
entry.content:
When lowercase letters are entered as input in CONVERSION_EXIT_CUNIT_INPUT, no results appear.

Comocial unit(MSEH3) is 'kPU'.

Internal unit(MSEHI) is 'KPU'.

CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_CUNIT_INPUT'
EXPORTING
input = 'kPU'
language = sy-langu
IMPORTING
output = output_unit
EXCEPTIONS
unit_not_found = 1
OTHERS = 2.

When performing the above function, the output_unit has no value.

When debuging it, it seems that the input 'kPU' is being changed to ' KPU' when searching. Is this a bug?

The domain (MSEH3) is set to be case-sensitive.

entry.title: Re: Fixed Asset Migration with Asset Sub number errors
entry.content:
Hello @AikoFC 

Thank you for your follow-up

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Fixed Asset migration template does not include a column for the SAP asset number because internal numbering is assigned automatically during load.

Use the following key fields:

External/Legacy Company Code
External/Legacy Asset Number
External/Legacy Subnumber

For internal numbering with sub assets, retain the original Asset Number and assign Sub number as 0, 1, 2, 3â€¦ Note:0 for the main asset, 1/2/3 for sub-assets.

After migration, verify the internal â†” legacy mapping in Monitor Migration â†’ Results within the Migrate Your Data â€“ Migration Cockpit (F3473) app.

SAP Community-Migration Cockpit - A basic guide

Useful SAP References

SAP Help Public Cloud: Fixed asset â€“ Master data explicitly mentions that external sub numbers are transferred, while main assets are assigned internal numbers. This explains why there is no â€œSAP Asset Numberâ€ column in the template. SAP Help Portal-Asset AccountingFixed asset - Master data

KBA 3596371 outlines restrictions on migrating sub-assets sub numbers, emphasising that main assets should be migrated first followed by sub numbers. This process aligns with the internal numbering system and legacy-key approach. 3596371 - Error 'Main asset does not exist in company code' while Fixed Asset master data migration with Sub-assets

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: HOWTO redirect and/or filter sapgenpse output
entry.content:
Hi, I've faced the same issue, on windows OS it's easier to search the output of the console (in powershell and C#). On linux, I found a workaround:

Add the -log to the sapgenpse command, which outputs to stderr, then do an I\O redirection from stderr to a file (2>file.txt for example) and then you can grep the file:

./sapgenpse -log get_my_name -p [PSE path] -n Validity 2>validity.txt && grep NotAfter validity.txt

Let me know if this helps you ðŸ™‚

entry.content:
Hello,

I found this UoM in the table (puom_wh)

I don't know if it is semantically correct.

The workaround I found is to create the association with T006 in the CDS view,

expose the UoM field to have the correct association with the Quantity,

and add @Consumption.hidden:true to the UoM field

in this way no join is generated at runtime during data extraction / analysis / query.

(the association / join forces you to define manually the CDC delta mapping if needed).

entry.title: SAP BDC - Enhance a BW Data product with SAP Databricks
entry.content:
This two-part blog series â€” created by the Italian Solution Advisory team â€” provides an end-to-end guide for SAP BW customers looking to modernize their analytics landscape using SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

The following diagram summarizes the overall workflow of the activities:

The first chapter of the series is structured as follows:

1 - Create a data product subscription to a custom BW infoprovider and replicate the data into SAP BDC
2 - Govern the custom data product access by data catalog sharing

The second one will be available shortly with this content:

3 - Derive insights by leveraging SAP Databricks ML capabilities
4 - Incorporate results to support business decisions

Our goal is to demonstrate how SAP BDC can accelerate BW modernization â€” delivering a state-of-the-art, end-to-end data management and analytics experience.

Prerequisites

The BW Data Product Generator requires at least the following product versions:

  • SAP BW 7.50 SP24 PCE
  • SAP BW/4HANA 2021 SP4 PCE
  • SAP BW/4HANA 2023 SP00 PCE

Our Suggested product version as of September 2025 (to include SAP NOTE 3596356 and 3628590) are the followings:

  • SAP BW 7.50 SP34
  • SAP BW/4HANA 2021 SP13
  • SAP BW/4HANA 2023 SP06

Note: This blog does not cover configuration steps â€” we assume the system has been set up according to the guidance in SAP Note 3590400

In our example we will use as source SAP BW/4HANA 2023 SP03

Create a data product subscription to custom BW infoprovider and replicate the data into SAP BDC

In BW/4HANA, weâ€™ve created a very simple model to collect data from the FI_GL_4 datasource connected to SAP S/4HANA, then a straightforward Composite Provider (ZIT_CFGLI) on top of the persistent ADSO

We developed also a process chain to provision the data periodically:

Weâ€™ll use the Data product Generator (DPG) on the Composite provider

To start, open the BW/4HANA Cockpit. If your user has the role SAP_BW4_MODELER_FOR_BDC youâ€™ll see a dedicated tab with giving access to the Data Subscription app:

The app lists all the current subscriptions (including attempted ones) and provide an overall status:

To create a new subscription just hit o the Create button and in the following form select the BW infoprovider you want to subscribe to:

Depending on the BW version the supported infoproviders are:

  • Physical providers: Infocubes, DSO and ADSO, InfoObjects
  • Virtual providers: Composite provider and Multiprovider
  • Query as infoprovider

Once the source infoprovider is selected just click on Save at the bottom

At this stage, nothing is generated. To generate the target artifact in SAP Datasphere, it is necessary to activate the subscription.

Before activating, here aresome details about the current options available with the DPG:

  • Settings Tab:
    • It allows to select between Full or Delta execution mode, currently Delta and Streaming mode is not supported.

  • it allows to set filters

  • it allows to link a process chain variant:

    A specific process variant: Data Provisioning Subscription (in section Load Process and Postprocessing) allow to link the update of the data in the data product with the execution of a process chain

     
    • Projections Tab
      • it allows to exclude some columns from the visibility in the Data product
    • Local table Tab
      • it contains log information available after the Run

    With the activation a new artifact will be deployed in a dedicated Datasphere Space the deploys data on SAP HANA Data lake files

    This space doesnâ€™t allow  any transformation of data or further modeling. It is designed to receive the BW infoprovider metadata and data and make it shareable with other spaces in SAP Datasphere, in details:

    • You cannot change the properties of the local tables (file) generated from SAP BW.
    • Delta capture is either OFF or ON, and you can't change it. If it's OFF, it won't track the delta capture changes, but it will keep historical snapshot versions.
    • Restoring to a previous version is not possible. You can only display a previous version.
    • If partitions were defined on the SAP BW side at table creation, you can see them (but you can't change them or create new ones).
    • Find and Replace is not available.

    At this stage we can activate our subscription with the Activate button at the bottom

     A background job in SAP Datasphere will be responsible for creating and deploying a Local Table (File) in the BW target space, this will take a couple of minutes.

     

    This is the reference architecture available from the help.sap.com   

    What you can then see in SAP Datasphere in the BW target space is the following:

    With the Activation weâ€™ve create the structure of the target table, no data have been replicated yet, to do so is necessary to run the job that provisions the data:

    The run starts an asynchronous job that transfers all the data, based on the settings that have been defined.

    Depending on the amount of data, youâ€™ll then see your records in the Datasphere table:

Govern the Custom data product access by data catalog sharing

Now that the BW data is available in SAP Datasphere, we can create a Data Product â€” making it shareable and consumable across other BDC services.

To create the Data product, weâ€™ll use the Data Sharing Cockpit in Datasphere.

In this section, weâ€™ll focus only on the key steps to complete the workflow. For detailed guidance on the Data Sharing Cockpit, refer to the official SAP documentation.

First of all make sure to have a valid Data Provider profile enabled or create a new one (link)

The fundamental property that is necessary to set in the profile is the Data provider\Data product visibility to Formations, this will allow to share data products within all services belonging to SAP BDC

Once a valid Data provider profile has been set up, is possible to create the data product from My Data product (link)

Provide a Business name and a Technical name to the Data Product:

Assign a meaningful description:

And product details:

In section Product artifacts is necessary to select the Datasphere Space where BW targets the generation of artifacts via DPG and then with Add artifacts button insert the Local Table(file) we created

At the end just save the changes

Once the Product is saved is necessary to switch the status to List:

We can now see the data product in the Datasphere Catalog:

The same data product is also obviously visible within SAP BDC Cockpit

Stay tuned for the next chapter of this series, where weâ€™ll share the newly created Data Product with SAP Databricks and enhance it using machine learning capabilities.

entry.title: Reminder Email Before Opportunity Close Date in SAP Sales Cloud v2
entry.content:
Dear CRM Experts,

I have a simple customer requirement regarding SAP Sales Cloud v2:

Send a reminder email to the opportunity owner 4 hours before the expected close date, if the opportunity is still open.

Do you have any ideas or suggestions on how this requirement could be implemented in v2?

Thank you very much,
Giovanni

entry.title: Re: Connecting to API via Public IP â€“ Disabling SSL Validation in CPI
entry.content:
Hi @KanishkaDeshak 

Apparently you are missing a certificate while accessing the endpoint, that is what the message says. Better option than disabling the SSL is to import the certificate of that web server. The reason it works from Postman is that Postman works a bit like a web-client and it imports the necessary certificates of that web server it is accessing without you knowing it. It is the same mechanism as opening a web page - you don't need to import any certificate, it happens in the background, but it is SSL-encrypted connection.

If you can access that domain from a web browser (doesn't need to be exact path, the same domain is enough), try to export the certificate, import it into CPI keystore and use that certificate in the integration.

In the web browser you should be able to see site information at the left side of the URL. There you select 'Connection is secure' and export the certificate.

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Event Mesh: Concepts, Setup, and Best Practices
entry.content:
What Is SAP Event Mesh?
SAP Event Mesh allows applications to communicate through asynchronous events.

SAP Event Mesh is a fully-managed service to connect applications, services, and systems so they can interact with each other through messages and events.

  • Publish business events
    Publish business events from SAP and non-SAP sources across hybrid landscapes from the digital core to extension applications through event-driven architecture.
  • Connect seamlessly
    Achieve reliable data transmission for extension and integration scenarios through decoupled communication.
  • Consume business events
    Consume business events from SAP and non-SAP sources throughout SAP's event-driven ecosystem including SAP Extension Suite, SAP Integration Suite, and selected inbound enabled SAP backends.
  • SAP Event Mesh supports standard messaging protocols to connect applications, services, and systems across hybrid landscapes.

Some Messaging Protocols

  • Advanced Messaging Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 over WebSocket is an open standard protocol for messaging between applications or organizations.
  • The defining features of AMQP are message orientation, queuing, routing (including point-to-point and publish-and-subscribe), reliability and security.
  • Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) 3.1.1 over WebSocket is a lightweight messaging protocol designed for low bandwidth, high latency. It is the recommended protocol for use by applications not running in the cloud.
  • HTTP 1.1 REST support allows to expose messaging capabilities using REST APIs.
  • Messages can be published to and consumed from queues and topics via HTTP REST calls.
  • You can use the AMQP 1.0 over WebSocket libraries and MQTT 3.1.1. over WebSocket libraries for node.js.
  • SAP Event Mesh also supports protocol-agnostic libraries that can be used at application configuration level for Java and Node.js.

What are Events?

Events are occurrences that signify a change in the state of data.

In the terms of information technology, events can range from a sensor detecting a shift in temperature, clicking a button in an application or creating or changing a Sales Order, modification of database record, completion of Bank transaction.

What is Messaging?

Messaging is a method by which applications communicate data to one another through a structured system of messages.

This system enables the exchange of information without requiring the applications to be directly connected or aware of each other's specific locations.

Key Participants in Messaging

  1. Publisher: Also known as the producer, this is the source that originates and dispatches a message.
  2. Message: This is the content dispatched by the publisher, which may include event details, enquiries, directives, and various other data. 
  3. Event Broker: The framework responsible for conveying the message from the publisher to the subscriber.
  4. Subscriber: Also referred to as the consumer, this is the final recipient of the message.

In EDA Event Driven Architecture, messages are directed to specific destinations that differentiate the sender (publisher) from the receiver (subscriber).
Within the SAP Advanced Event Mesh, these destinations are commonly topic endpoints or queues, both of which are coordinated by event brokers.

  • Queues ensure messages are received by no more than one subscriber.
  • Topic endpoints facilitate the delivery of messages to multiple subscribers.

 

 Event Driven Architecture (EDA)

Message Exchange Patterns

Dictate how messages are dispatched and retrieved, each serving distinct scenarios and
requirements

1. Publish-Subscribe:

  • This pattern is frequently used for events. Producers publish messages to a central hub without specifying a particular consumer.
  • The event broker then disseminates these messages to all the subscribers who have shown interest in that type of message.
  • It's particularly effective for sending out widespread notifications, such as alerting multiple parts of a system to a user's action.

Publish-Subscribe

2. Point-to-Point/Exclusive Consumption:

  • Messages in this pattern is directed to a specific queue and consumed by only one recipient.
  • This ensures that a single consumer processes each message, which is crucial for tasks where one, and only one, process must handle the message, such as order processing.

Point-to-Point/Exclusive Consumption

2.1. Non-Exclusive Consumption:

  • Consumer groups can be applied to enhance the classic point-to-point messaging framework.
  • They allow several consumers to collectively use a single queue that acts as the unique conduit for messages emanating from the producer.
  • Even though there may be numerous consumers within the receiving application, each message is guaranteed to be delivered to just one endpoint.

 

Non-Exclusive Consumption 

What are Event Brokers?

  • An event broker in an event-driven architecture (EDA) is an intermediary that routes messages from producers to consumers based on subscriptions.
  • Applications publish events to the broker, which then distributes these messages to interested clients.
  • This broker can be a physical device, on-premises software, or a cloud-based service.
  • It supports various exchange patterns like publish/subscribe and integrates with different systems, including SAP Integration Suite, Solace, and Kafka.
  • By enabling an event mesh, it ensures efficient, targeted communication across diverse environments, acting as a centralized system for managing event-driven messaging.

SAP Event Mesh supports central messaging concepts:

1. Queues

  • A queue is a collection in which the entities in the collection are kept in order and the main operations on the queue are the addition of entities to the rear terminal position and removal of entities from the front terminal position.
  • SAP Event Mesh enables applications to communicate with each other through message queues. A sending application sends a message to a specific named queue. There's a one-to-one correspondence between a
    receiving application and its queue. The message queue retains the messages until the receiving application consumes it.
  • You can manage these queues using the SAP Event Mesh dashboard.

2. Topics

  • Topics are named logical channels to which messages are published.
  • Subscribers in a topic-based system receive all messages published to the topics to which they have subscribed.
  • All subscribers to a topic receive their own copy of the same message.

   

 

 

 

 

SAP Event Mesh enables a sending application to publish messages and events to a topic.

Applications must be subscribed to that topic and be active when the message is sent. Topics do not retain messages. This method can be used when each message needs to be consumed by a number of receiving applications.

Queue Subscriptions

  • With queue subscriptions SAP Event Mesh enables a sending application to publish messages to a topic.
    The topic sends the message directly to the queue to which it is bound. For example, events from an SAP S/4HANA system (event source) can only be sent to a topic.
  • A queue subscription ensures that the message is retained until it is consumed by the receiving application.

Topics with Event-Driven Architecture (EDA)

  • Topics within an Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) function as a method for categorizing event messages.
  • They resemble directories that channel similar events into specific streams.
  • Events are associated with topics by publishers, and endpoints, or subscribers, choose topics to receive
    relevant events.

Subscriptions to Topics: Subscriptions are formulated using strings that may include wildcard characters to
capture a broad selection of topic messages.
The wildcards * and > are typically used for this purpose.
* This symbol acts as a placeholder that can represent any value at a specific level within the topic.

Message Delivery Modes

  • In SAP Integration Suite with advanced event mesh supports two primary types of message delivery, each serving different use cases based on the requirements for speed and reliability:
    1. Direct Messaging
    2. Guaranteed Messaging

1. Direct messaging is a form of communication in event-driven systems designed for scenarios that require fast and efficient message delivery, but where it's acceptable that some messages might not be delivered in cases of congestion or failure.

2. Guaranteed messaging or persistent messaging is a reliable message delivery system used in applications where it's critical that no messages are lost.

The main features of guaranteed messaging include:

  • Durable Subscriptions: Topic subscriptions are tied to a stable endpoint within the event broker, not
    directly to the transient clients. This ensures continuity and message integrity over time.
  • Message Persistence: Once the event broker confirms (acknowledges) receipt of a message, the
    message is considered safe and will not be lost, even in the event of system failures.
  • Message Retention: Messages are stored at a durable endpoint within the broker until a client
    retrieves and processes them, regardless of the client's connection status.
  • Acknowledged Delivery: When a message is successfully delivered and processed by a client, the
    client sends back an acknowledgement to the broker, confirming receipt.

 

Hands-on 

  1. Create account on Solace.com 
  2. Go to Solace->Click on Cluster manager 
 

       3. Click on Create Service 

  • Same page below - we have an Advance Connection Options here we can port of all the adapters like  , 

  • Creating the Queue, 

 

  • Default below image, and click and apply top right corner

  • Now, we are going to create iflow in SAP CPI. 

  • We need to give the host name of the event broker (solace host name) 

  • In Solace, Go to Cluster and Open the Connect tab,

  • Connection details below mentioned the screenshot, 

 

 

 

  • We have sent 1 message through postman and received the solace in queue below image, 

     

     

  • Second iflow creating for Event_Mesh_Receiver, 

    Usecase:1 

    We have stored using 1st iflow in queue now we are trying to fetch the message in queue using 2nd iflow. 

     

     

     

     

     

  • After running the iflow data has been stored in Data store below, 

SAP Event Mesh Sending Messages using REST API

  • Now, we are going to send data from Postman to Solace (Event Broker).

API URL

For Queue:

https://mr-connection-dwwfdwq848z.messaging.solace.cloud:9443/queue/SalesOrderQueue 

For Topic:

https://mr-connection-dwwfdwq848z.messaging.solace.cloud:9443/topic/SalesOrderQueue 

Trigger from postman its directly went through event broker (Solace)â€”From solaceâ€”we are fetching the data through CPI and store on datastore. 

 

  • Now , we are using topic to post the data, 
  • Click here the queue , and then go to subscription and then create topic,

 

 

 

 

  • Sender is postman for this scenario, 

  • Go to CPI change to consumer mode is Direct and added the Topic Subscriptions, 

 

  • We are posting: 
  • POSTMAN--->Solace-->CPI-->Datastore 

SAP EVENT MESH Publishing Messages using AMQP 

  • Go to solace->Connect->choose(protocol)-->Go to AMQP-->Select AMQP open source API.

 

 

 

 

 

Conclusion

This blog provides a comprehensive guide to integrating SAP Event Mesh with Solace Event Broker to enable robust, event-driven communication between distributed systems. Theoretically, it introduces the concept of SAP Event Mesh as a messaging infrastructure that facilitates asynchronous data exchange using queues and topics, supporting protocols like REST and AMQP. Solace is used as the event broker to manage message routing and delivery. The hands-on section walks through the practical steps of setting up a Solace account, creating services, queues, and topics, and configuring SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) to send and receive messages. Two iFlows are developedâ€”one for publishing messages to Solace and another for consuming them and storing the data in a datastore. The guide also demonstrates sending messages via Postman using REST APIs and AMQP, showcasing how messages flow from external sources through Solace to CPI. Overall, the document effectively bridges theory and practice, illustrating how SAP Event Mesh and Solace can be used together to build scalable, decoupled, and real-time integration scenarios.

entry.title: How to create and trigger RAP based event via Event Mesh
entry.content:
Hello,

This blog is an attempt to show steps to create RAP based events and how to trigger events via ABAP in Event Mesh.

This blog is written on S/4 HANA 2023 private cloud . Also it assumes that you know the basics of RAP ABAP.

Let's start !

 

  1. Create a Root Entity:

2. Create behaviour definition of above root entity. Raise an event as shown below , Parameter is optional if you just want to trigger an event  you can do so but if you have to send some value to CPI alongwith event ,you will raise it with Parameter and will pass the parameter. Here we want to send timestamp , so we have created similar parameter.

3. Once we have passed the parameter , we will create an abstract entity for same parameter(with same name of entity). Though the name is hidden below but it has to be same as parameter name.

4. Once you are done with above , you will also create your class in Behaviour definition and in tab â€œGlobal Classâ€ , we will declare static method as well(Declaration and Implementation). The lhc_i_hubtr_out mentioned below is local handler class and itâ€™s method â€œTrigger eventâ€ we will create in next step.

5. Now , we will go to â€œLocal typesâ€ tab as shown below and will create our â€œtrigger_eventâ€ method as shown below to call RAISE ENTITY and call the event which we created in 2nd step along with Parameter. Activate behavior definition , Root and abstract entities once done.

6. Now, we will call method in ABAP . The method created in â€œglobal classâ€ section will be called and in turn it will call â€œtrigger_eventâ€. We cannot do RAISE ENTITY EVENT from ABAP because it can only be called from Behaviour definition, So that is why we created a global method and then calling that global method in ABAP .

After calling this method, Donâ€™t forget to write â€œCOMMIT  WORKâ€ , otherwise your event will not be registered.

7. We will also create an event binding as shown below. You can provide any Namespace, Object type and Operation. But you need to choose your root entity and event name which you created in earlier steps by clicking on Add button.

8. Once done with above steps, last step is to configure the namespace as shown below in tcode /n/IWXBE/CONFIG. Select the channel and click on â€œOutbound Bindingsâ€.

Click on below highlighted â€œCreateâ€ button

After this a popup of Topic will be populated, in f4 select the event binding created in 7th Step as shown below

Once you add it , it will be added to outbound channel. This channel will be visible to CPI and then see it in their queue , how many records have come via this channel.


9. Now as soon as you trigger this event(By running your ABAP report), you can check via t-code /n/IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR that whether those events are triggered or not. There are 2 tabs â€“ Inbound & Outbound and we can check as per our event raised. Below is the screenshot of our event raised.

Click on AEM_BROKER and below is the screenshot showing 2 records triggered.

This is the end of this blog and if there is any questions or something missing, please write to me on sharma.vimal@accenture.com OR  vimal.sharma041@gmail.com 

 

Thanks,

Vimal

entry.title: Re: Group Chart of Accounts in S/4 Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi,

Group chart of account YGR1 is delivered by scope item 3AF and can be used for consolidation in external system. Check out 2944535 - Field "Group chart of account" is not available for more information.

Group chart of accounts Y1 is  the consolidation chart of Accounts which is used in S/4HANA Group Reporting which comes with scope item 1SG.

Best regards,
Jonathan

entry.title: Re: Correct config to release returned stock from Blocked...
entry.content:
Dear @SAPSupport,

Based on the customer's needs, my recommendation is as follows:

I would set defaults values in CBC (ID: 106585), which will be suggested in the documents after selecting the goods. This will minimize manual work, overrides are available.

 

 

Why use Follow-UP Activity: Receive into Plant:

  • Physically brings the returned goods into your own plant/warehouse so you can handle them yourself (inspect, repair, decide next steps).

When use:

  • You want to inspect/test/repair the product before deciding.

Result:

  • System automatically created Customer Return Delivery, so you have full control over the process, you know exactly what is the status of returns by filtering on every steps (Ready for Picking, Ready to Post GI or GI Posted)

 

 

 

 

In the next step, we perform quality checks. With the settings I suggested here, we also have full process control based on your comment about (Perform the follow-up activity in the delivery. Execute decision codes to complete QA). Please see the status below from Enter Inspection Results â€“ From Warehouse app. I choose delivery items waiting for inspection and system show me my document.

 

 

You decide where the goods will go after inspection, please see fields Target Storage Loc: and Target Stock Type.

Important: After created PGR system automatically put in Stock Type (Blocked Stock) this is how SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud logic works without editable option.

 

 

The process I described solves the observed problems, except for one: specifying the target stock type on QC.

I hope this suggestion/solution helps.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: How to Enable Batch Input in Fiori inside the Systemâ€™s Services
entry.content:
In this Blog, I will explain the complete process of enabling Batch input option inside the systemâ€™s Services.

Why is Batch Input needed?  What are the Features of Batch Input?

A Batch Input Session in SAP is a method used to automate data entry by recording and processing transactions. It involves creating a session that contains a sequence of steps to execute transactions, which can then be processed in either foreground or background mode.

Features

  • Synchronous Processing in database update.
  • Transfer data for more than one transaction.
  • Batch input processing log will be generated.
  • During processing, no transaction is started until the previous transaction has been written to the database. 

How to add this Batch input option in Fiori Screen?

  •  To activate the Batch input option, you need to add the authorization object inside the respective role which is  S_Develop.                                                                                                             

     

How to add this object in Fiori?

      Step 1: Navigate to pfcg Tcode

      Step 2: Find the Exact role

      Step 3:  Navigate to authorization tab, Find the S_develop tcode using Ctrl+F or else use                              Manually add option

      Step 4: Maintain the Required Authorization values

  • OBJTYPE = DEBUG
  • OBJNAME = * (or restrict to specific programs)
  • ACTIVITY = 03 or 02 (Access to Display or Access to Change)

      Step 5: Save and Generate the Authorization profile.

      Step 6: Assign the role to user using the SU01 tcode. 

      

 

Result:

Once refresh the Fiori Screen, the system will automatically add Batch Input under System-Services- Batch Input

Note:

  • Avoid Giving Broad Access (*) in production for S_Develop object.
  • Always validate with your Security team before adding authorization objects.
  • Provide only necessary activities alone (eg. Display)                                                                                 Conclusion:

With these steps Batch input is enabled under the systemâ€™s services and accessible in Fiori Screen.
